text:
I really love this dish. I have made it a few times. The first time, I followed the directions exactly. It had really good flavor, but I didn't like the way the flour on the chicken got slimy on the chicken. The second time I still followed the original recipe but I left out the flour and it was perfect and that's how I'll make it from now on. The balsamic reduction was delicious. I always use portobellos as the mushrooms. Fantastic! This is one of the best recipes I have tried off this website! Other than omitting the flour this recipe needs no variations! Thanks Colleen

text:
I am giving this 10 stars!!!!! I loved this. Very easy to prepare and it just reeked of professionalism. Next time, I may leave out the whole flour thing because it didn't really add anything to the dish. Also, I only ended up with enough sauce for two chicken breasts instead of four (think I reduced the sauce too long). Beautiful recipe. Went great with a California Zinfindel (Campus Oaks, Lodi, 2000).  Also, I did flatten my breasts before seasoning and flouring so they would cook more evenly. Very  tender and moist chicken. Can you tell that I loved this recipe? I am planning on making this many more times for friends and for parties. THANK YOU!!!

I love this, it is my favorite recipe from this site! If you're not a vinegar lover I suggest using only 1/8 cup of balsamic vinegar. I love the vinegar flavor so I wouldn't change a thing. I use white balsamic vinegar (looks nicer). And... I use 1.5 lb. of mushrooms, 1 cup chicken broth and 10 cloves of garlic.

text:
This was great; cooked it with a friend.  We did change a couple of things, though.  First, we cut the chicken into strips & added garlic powder to the flour mixture.  Then browned the chicken & removed from pan.  Sauteed garlic for just a minute, then dumped in double the sauce ingredients.  We reduced the sauce for about 8-10 minutes, then added the chicken back in and continued reducing for 10 minutes, then added the butter.  We browned the mushroom separately and added them in just before serving.  YUM! **Note:I made this again and didn't bother with flouring the chicken, I just sprinkled a little wondra towards the end of cooking and then added the sauce right to the pan.  Just as good and way easier!

text:
4-1/2 stars as written. However, with a few simple additions you can swing this over into the 5 star stratosphere! No treatment of the garlic cloves is mentioned, so I peeled them, crushed and very finely minced 2 of the cloves (to make the garlic flavor more pronounced,) leaving the rest whole. Also added 2 Tb finely minced shallots, which gave lots of depth of flavor. If you don't have or can't find shallots, green onions will do.  If you find the taste to be too acidic, then look to your balsamic vinegar as the culprit. The only type to use is from Modena, Italy. Others are just imitators. A genuine Modena balsamic is smooth as silk, with no bite. It costs more, but in a dish such as this, it makes a world of difference. Once the breasts are pounded thin, cooking them for 10 minutes in liquid is WAY too much. After you've browned them, they need very little time. Just make your sauce as directed (also added a little marjoram, white pepper, and a tsp Dijon mustard to increase flavor complexity,) turn off the heat, and allow your already-browned breasts to steep in the sauce covered for 10 minutes on top of the burner. This is known as carry-over cooking, and the heat of the sauce is quite sufficient to finish off any undercooked meat. Skipping the flour coating works just fine. However, to thicken the sauce enough to coat noodles or potatoes, whisk 2-3 tsp of flour to the room temp stock, then stir this into the pan, stirring until sauce reaches a boil. Finishing the sauce

text:
This recipe is just wonderful!  My husband and children found it had a bit too much vinegar even when I cut the amount in half.  So the next time I made it I added about 2tbsp of cream when the sauce was cooked.  It might sound strange but it really helped richen the flavor and take the bite out of the vinegar.  This recipe also works well with pounded, boneless, skinless chicken thighs.  Thanks for this recipe, it's a family favorite! :) Barb in BC

text:
An excellent dish! I also doubled the garlic, letting the whole cloves simmer in the broth until they became soft and sweet. For a totally different taste, throw a can of chopped tomatoes in at the same time as you add the vinegar; simmer the whole thing together and you have yourself a similiar but more robust meal. Cuts down on the acidity of the vinegar too. 
A really easy and impressive dinner!

text:
Fabulous!!! A new favorite. I read numerous reviews & then decided to do it my way.  I doubled the sauce ingredients since I wanted to serve over pasta.  This includes the vinegar, I don't know what the people that said they cut back or thought it was too vinegary were thinking, they must eat really pland food, because I thought it was good, could have even used more.  As for the comments about not coating the chicken, again I disagree.  This is how I did it:  I wilted the mushrooms & removed from the pan, added a little oil heated it to high, added the coated chicken and cooked until golden on both sides.  Added the sauce  ingredients & mushrooms back in & cooked covered about 5 minutes until the chicken was done * removed it.  Then I simmered uncovered until the sauce was reduced & added cooked pasta.  Served chicken over pasta & sauce.  Getting the coating crispy before adding the sauce keeps it from getting slimy & adds texture & golden brown deliciousness.   Will make again & again, & want to try with some thin pork chops.

text:
I browned the chicken in olive oil instead of butter – removed from skillet & kept warm in the oven.  I then sautéed onion, garlic & mushrooms together for approx. 5 min.  I then added the balsamic vinegar & chicken broth (which I doubled to use for gravy on mashed potatoes) allowing the liquid to reduce for approx. another 5 min. before returning the chicken to the pan.  I turned the chicken a few times in the sauce & cooked covered for 4-6 additional min.  Mashed potatoes & a side salad &dinner was ready in less than 40 minutes.  This recipe is a keeper!

text:
Everyone enjoyed this, even my 5 year old. I took suggestions from other reviewers and didn't flour the chicken...I'm glad I didn't, it turned out perfectly and very tender. I also used portabello mushrooms, they have a great flavor and don't go "soggy" like regular mushrooms. Finally, I would definitely recommend sticking with the 1/4 cup of balsamic vingar as called for in the original recipe. I was just shy of the 1/4 cup because I was worried about it being too tart (based on other reviews). It definitely requires the quarter cup for full flavor. I served with wild rice pilaf and steamed broccoli. A very simple and quick recipe, light in calories and full in flavor = a keeper

I really had some issues with this recipe. First, it was very bitter as-is to the point of utter bluntness. I had to add about two tablespoons of brown sugar to try and tone down the bitterness. It also just lacked flavor overall. Compare this to something like the chicken in red wine sauce recipe on this site and you'll see what I mean. That recipe (if you follow reviewers suggested changes) is full of depth and flavor. This one -- not so much. I wanted to love this recipe but it was just lacking in a big way. There are many better chicken recipes on this site.

userID:
2972545
Display Name:
BelfastJimmy
isPro:

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this dish last night. Following others' recommendations I too omitted the flour but added Paprika to the seasoning mix of salt and pepper. The Bay leaf was omitted also since I had run out of them.
I used Canola Oil to get a higher temperature thereby quickening the browning process of the breasts.

The one thing that I would do differently with this recipe would be to use 1/8 cup of Balsamic Vinegar rather than 1/4.
I felt the vinegar proved a little too bitter so I had to add a sprinkling of brown sugar and some honey to get it back to my taste level.
The "Cucino Balsamic Vinegar of Modena" used had an acidity level of 6% .
I also used a full cup of chicken broth as opposed to 3/4.
6 garlic cloves could be overkill depending upon your love of garlic. Instead I used 2 'jumbo' cloves finely sliced.

To make the dish more visually appealing I added 1/2 chopped Red Bell pepper to the sauce as well as sliced Portobello mushrooms and the regular white mushrooms.

After adding butter to the sauce I opted for a smoother quality with the addition of 1 - 2 teaspoons of cornflour mixed with a little water.
This VASTLY improved the sauce consistency.
Using an electric knife I sliced each breast into 1/4 inch slices and served with a medley of steamed vegetables and boiled 'baby' potatoes.

I was nervous because I am not a huge fan of balsamic vinegar and the reviews all say this has a very strong flavor. This was sooo good! I loved it. I used jarred minced garlic and I wish that I had used fresh, but this was still an amazing dish. You will want to pound the chicken to about 1/4 inch thick. The thicker parts of the chicken do not absorb the flavor as well as the thinner parts.

text:
OH YUM! Wow, that is a good recipe. I doubled the sauce and still wanted more so will triple it next time. I didn't know what to do with the garlic so I just flattened it with a knife blade. I also took one cook's advice and added a half of a sliced white onion at the same time as the garlic. I served over pasta. This dish is simple enough for any night and sexy enough for guests. It's going into regular rotation at our house!

***UPDATE*** I made this again last night but quadrupled the sauce. Not a good idea!!! It stayed watery and really vinegary. I even tried to thicken it with tapioca starch. It did not work. Stick to the original recipe or just double the sauce like I did the first time, or use two pans so that the sauce can spread out and caramelize. Aside from last night's fiasco, this is still my new favourite recipe!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this tonight and there was no leftovers!! Even my 4 year old liked it. 

I did make a few changes, but mostly everything I had in my pantry. I skipped the flouring of the chicken and just used S&P. I only had 4 cloves of garlic, but had some minced garlic in the fridge so used 2 TBS of that (we like garlic)
 I used a can of concentrated chicken broth (all I had) and mixed it with 1 cup of water, heated it through on the stove. I used the the amount of broth as the recipe called for, and added 2 TBS of cornstarch to thicken the sauce a bit, it tasted too vinegary for my liking so I added the rest of the broth and 3 TBS of cream cheese, covered and simmered until the cheese was soft and then stirred until smooth. WOW it was delicious. For a side I made plain penne with butter and parmesean but I ended up using half the sauce to top the chicken and mixing the rest in with the noodles. It was DELICIOUS. WILL DEFINITELY MAKE AGAIN!!

country:
None
text:
This chicken is amazing!  You must like balsamic vinegar in order to appreciate this restaurant-quality dish.  The sauce is very similar in taste to a marsala sauce (which I love).  I did make a few changes.  I didn't dredge the chicken in flour but I did butterfly the chicken breasts so they would be thin, tender, and have more surface area to absorb the sauce.  I added about 1 C. chopped tomato at the same time the mushrooms were added.  Next time I will double the broth, balsamic, garlic, thyme, and butter because I wish there had been more sauce once it was reduced.  The reduction was absolutely delicious!  I served the chicken with roasted potatoes and drizzled the sauce over everything.  This dish would be great with fresh, crusty baguette to dip in the leftover sauce.

text:
Great recipe but turned out a little on the dry side.  I would recommend doubling the amount of mushrooms, thyme, bay leaves, balsamic vinegar and broth (and letting it simmer for about 18 min rather than 10 at the end).  That way, you can cook up some mashed potatoes and lay a piece of chicken on top and then drizzle the sauce on top on the plate.  I would also recommend cutting the garlic into quarters so that more of the flavor is absorbed and can also be eaten with the mushrooms and sauce, otherwise the cloves/chunks are little overwhelming.  Great recipes and will definitely make it again.

text:
This was very delicious! I'm not eating any flour at the moment (or probably ever again), so I totally cut it out of the dish and it was absolutely perfect. Followed the suggestion of another user and turned the pan up really high and browned each side of the chicken, then I turned it down to low to cook the garlic and mushrooms. Worked like a charm. The chicken got a little dry, so next time I will more carefully monitor it, to make sure it doesn't go above 170 degrees cooking. After we ate the dinner, my boyfriend had the brilliant idea of saving the left over sauce, thickened with a little cornstarch and using it on caprese salad. I had a bite and it was delicious!

text:
This was EXCELLENT!!  And it may be the best balsamic chicken recipe I’ve made. I skipped the flour and just sprinkled the chicken with salt and pepper. I also changed the process by completely cooking my chicken and removing it to a warm oven.   Then I browned the mushrooms and added the garlic for about 30 seconds and then proceeded with the sauce.  I got a little impatient waiting for the sauce to reduce, so after swirling the butter in, I added just a little cornstarch mixed with cold water, and in no time I had a lovely sauce.  I think my method is easier and there’s no chance of overcooking the chicken.  Try it!!

text:
Extremely yummy. I only used 3 chicken breasts since mine were huge; otherwise followed all directions. The flour dredging didn't seem to add anything, as most of the coating came off while cooking even though I tried to mess with the chicken as little as possible. Seemed like a lot of garlic but it was not overpowering at all; directions didn't say so I just slivered each clove into 4 pieces. I did sprinkle a tiny bit of flour into the sauce at the end to thicken it a bit. This turned out great and I will make it again! UPDATE: Made this again and turned it into sandwiches, which were amazing! Put chicken and mushrooms on a toasted bun, topped with melted provolone and used the liquid for dipping...this time I used portobello mushrooms too, which were excellent. Skipped the flour dredging step.

text:
Very VERY tasty and simple to make.  I adapted the recipe to a baked version because we're watching our fat and calories.  I left off the 3 T of olive oil and browned my chicken using a olive oil spray, deglazed the saute pan with chicken stock, baked everything covered in a medium baking dish gently at 375 for 1 hour, and left off the butter. We used the pan juices as they were but next time I'll try thickening them with cornstarch.  Very good recipe, thanks bunches!

Wow, I am SO impressed with this recipe!!!  I was worried it would be too salty, but it's absolutely perfect!  Because I am a mushroom hater, I left then out (Yay, extra sauce for the chicken!).  I also followed others advice and omitted the flour.  Other than these changes, I made the recipe as written.  The chicken was super moist and had exactly the right amount of flavor!  I will definitely be making this many more times, and look forward to impressing guests with it as well!  Thanks for the great recipe!  :) UPDATE 4/16/09:  I made this again tonight, but threw in sliced zucchini in place of the mushrooms, and added a little bit of flour at the very end to thicken the sauce a bit....WOW!!!!!  Best version yet...can't wait to try it with other veggies now!  By the way, the balsamic reduction is absolutely wonderful paired with a glass of Chardonney....it compliments the all of the flavors prefectly!

text:
Chicken Breasts w/ Balsamic Vinegar & Garlic Haiku: "'Gravy too bitter. But chicken was pretty good. Needs changes for me." If I was to make this again, I'd reduce the balsamic vinegar, increase the garlic, and reduce the thyme. The thyme and balsamic overpowered the gravy (I skipped flouring the chicken and instead added a TB of flour that I'd mixed w/ cold water into the pan at the end), but the mushrooms were quite nice. The chicken itself, having cooked it per the instructions, was done just right in texture and taste. I served it w/, as suggested, roasted potatoes, which we dragged through the mushroom sauce, but we weren't overly impressed.

text:
We love this recipe, and my husband has asked me to make it for a dinner party. I made this recipe with the following changes: I marinated the chicken breasts in the balsamic vinegar in a plastic bag for 30 minutes. I started the sauce ingredients in a small saucepan ten minutes before the marinating time was up. I accidentally added 1/2 teaspoon thyme, but we love thyme with chicken, and I plan to make this exactly that way, next time. I used the George Foreman grill, grilling the mushrooms first for three minutes, then grilling the chicken breasts for 4 minutes.  I added the mushrooms 7 minutes before the sauce  and chicken was done. Other than that, I used all the listed ingredients, and it was delicious. I served this with white and wild rice and green beans. My mother in law, who takes a lot of coaxing to get enough protien dishes, loved this!
Review:

text:
I used the suggestion from several people not to put flour on the chicken. When I came time to reduce the sauce, I think the flour would have helped to thicken it. So I used 2 Tbsp of cornstarch mixed into 3/4 cup of cold water and added it to the sauce after it had reduced for about 7 or 8 minutes. This thickened it up just right. I am amazed at the great flavor considering there are no onions. We will be adding this to our recipe box for sure.

LOVE this recipe! I make it about twice a month. The only changes I have made was I add a little brown sugar (no more than a tablespoon). Just a personal preference in our household. text:
This was a tasty dish and I'll be making it again.  I sliced through the thicker chicken breasts so they would cook more evenly.  Though we enjoyed the vinegar flavor as something different, I'll likely reduce the amount a bit next time, perhaps to 3 tbsp.  I didn't flour the breasts before browning them, but added just the amount of Wondra to the sauce at the end to get it to the consistency I wanted.  I found the amount of sauce to be just right for serving the sauce with the chicken, but would want to make more sauce if I planned to serve it over pasta.

country:
None
text:
I made this as suggested excepting the flour which I just plain forgot. I suspect it's prescence is there to thicken the sauce so add it later, or cornstarch, whatever, or not, if you like a thin sauce. I kept my breasts whole, in future I would suggest cutting them in strips or pounding them flat. The flavour of the sauce is good but needs to be carried further into the chicken. This is a pretty simple dish and you could and probably should expand this a little to include some more complexity, a reduced red wine, some shallots, white pepper and sliced red peppers. For the record I've long since discovered the error of cooking with cheap Balsamic vinegar. Do not make any recipe requiring Balsamic vinegar with cheap stuff.

userID:

Display Name:
JennyF85
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/820761.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish was delicious - with a few modifications.  
If i were to make it as is, i would have to give it a 3 and a half star rating it just didn't seem to have enough flavor. 
First off i used only 2 plump chicken breasts (i was scared there wouldn't be enough sauce for 4). I not only seasoned the chicken with S&P and Flour, but also with cyan, seasoning salt, and paprika. 
After i had the chicken, mushrooms and garlic going, I then added the remaining ingredients along with 2 tbsp of honey, a few splashes of Worcestershire sauce, a splash of soy sauce, and a heaping tbsp of dijon mustard.  I left the chicken to  boil in this mixture until cooked through. I then removed the chicken and placed in the oven to keep warm. 
I then used cornstarch to thicken the sauce and poured over the chicken and served. 
My boyfriend and i really enjoyed this recipe and look forward to using it in the future.

text:
This was super yummy and pretty easy to make. I didn't have plain balsamic vinegar, so I used Fresh and Easy's brand "Balsamic Vinaigrette Dressing". I was afraid that would alter the taste, but it still came out delicious! It may have actually tempered the vinegar-y taste some of the other reviewers complained about. As the recipe stands, it makes *just* enough sauce for the chicken. And only for the four servings listed. I definitely wished there was more sauce for the pasta. I will probably try to double that part of the recipe in order to have extra sauce. But this recipe is a total keeper!

I was very pleasantly surprised by this recipe.  I thought that I'd like it but my daughter would be "meh" about it, but as it turned out, I loved it and so did my daughter! Definitely going into the recipe rotation in my house.  Thanks!

Display Name:
luv2bake

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fabulous! We love balsamic vinegar so this was a winner! I did change some things, per other reviews. I skipped the flour, mushrooms, and bay leaf. I cut the chicken breast in half to cook quicker, seasoned with salt, pepper and garlic powder and lightly browned on both sides. Put in remaining ingredients except the butter and simmered covered turning once until liquid reduced to half. Removed chicken. Then added butter and a little cornstarch (half Tbsp) to thicken. *If doing cornstarch remember to whip in a little cold water or broth before adding to pan or it will clump. Served over rice and steamed broccoli!

*CAVEAT*  I made a quick mock-up of this last night for dinner, using frozen grilled chicken strips, because I had to get dinner together very fast.  But apart from that, I made it as written and served it over whole-grain rotini.  DH and I both liked it a lot!  I'll definitely make it again, using fresh chicken; I might mess around slightly with more thyme, and possibly some black pepper next time.  I think this is going to become a staple around our house! It's easy, tasty, affordable, healthful, and uses things I always have in stock.   Thanks for posting!

text:
Very easy & good.  The recipe makes no mention of cutting up the garlic so I sliced them.  I omitted the butter & used a cornstarch whitewash in the sauce at the end instead of dredging the chicken in flour before frying.  I browned both sides of the meat before sauteeing the garlic & mushrooms.  The chicken breasts I used were quite large & took a lot more time to cook than stated.  Next time, I'll marinate the chicken with the salt, pepper & some balsamic vinegar for several hours first to give the meat more flavor.

text:
I was very impressed with this recipe!  The chicken was so tender and the sauce was so tasty.  I used only 2 chicken breasts but kept the sauce ingredients the same (omitted the mushrooms) and even added a little extra broth and vinegar as it simmered away near the end.  Forgot I was out of thyme so I used rosemary instead.  When simmering the sauce, I whisked in the leftover flour mixture to thicken it.  I did add the butter at the end, but it was so flavorful and thick it probably would have been great without it.  Everyone loved it here, and hubby rated it 5 stars!  Served with brown rice and steamed asparagus.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe turned out great. I don't think the 1/4 cup of balsamic is too much at all. I felt like it gave a great flavor. I pounded the chicken breasts and diced up 2 of the 6 garlic cloves and pretty much followed the directions as listed. After the 10 minutes of simmering, I pulled the chicken breasts out and thickened the mixture with a couple of tablespoons of cornstarch (make sure to dissolve the cornstarch in cold water if you do this). The result: a delicious balsamic reduction sauce with mushrooms that complimented the chicken breasts perfect. I've made this twice and served over rice both times and it was delicious.

Yummy! Nice result for being a 30 minute dish. Tried doubling the sauce the second time which didn't turn out well... at least I wouldn't double the vinegar again. My partner said the standard recipe gave a caramelized taste, so if doubling again I would cook as in the recipe and just add some extra chicken stock and flour to thicken at the end. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As written, I'd give this about a 3.5.  It was good, don't get me wrong, but there were some things about the recipe that were a little confusing.  

The garlic.  I threw the whole cloves of garlic into the skillet, but at that point, what do you do with them?  I didn't want to eat whole cloves, so, since they were pretty soft by that point, I ended up mashing them.  Next time, I'll probably run through the garlic press before I add them.

The sauce.  It gave the mushrooms a wonderful flavor, they really picked up the vinegar and were delicious, however, it didn't thicken at all until well after it had cooled.  I'd like to maybe try a little cornstarch/water mix, just to keep it from being so runny.

As chicken does, it took a little longer to cook, but the times listed are good guidelines.  I'll probably make this again with the changes above, because I think this could be a very good dish, but as is, it needs some tweaking.

All the credit to the contributor of this recipe!

text:
Really delicious recipe! I've never used balsamic vinegar before so I was a bit afraid, especially after reading some of the reviews. But I am delighted to say that I found the dish to be absolutely wonderful. It had a very light, clean taste; not too heavy. I will be making this again!

I did make a few changes: used chicken thighs, which I cut up into big chunks and did not use the flour as some suggested; I made 8 servings and used the "Adjust Recipe" button above to get the ingredients right (12 chicken thighs because they have less meat than chicken breasts); and I cooked some linguini and put everything into a big pot at the end.

text:
This chicken is delicious.  I more or less follow the recipe as written, except I use chicken breast tenders, which are thinner and more tender than whole breasts. I think it is important to use very good balsamic vinegar to avoid the bitter or sour taste that some reviewers commented on.  I have made this dish, refrigerated it overnight and heated it up the next day in a crockpot for a potluck.

None
text:
I have made this dish several times and I still always love it. A lot of people have commented about simmering and reducing their sauce to much... Solution, when you make up your chicken broth, whether it be through bouillon or can, and give yourself 1 1/4cup-1 1/2cup of broth. This way you can add more liquid if it reduces down to much with out sacrificing flavor or sauce. I also keep the heat on a mere simmer not medium low, to much heat dries the chicken out. Love this with linguine as suggested by another post. Also lovely with fresh broccoli and roasted potatoes!

Loved it...followed the recipe, I did coat the ckn with flour because I knew it would thicken the sauce.  It did it's job, the sauce was thick and rich. I used Baby Bella mushrooms it just gives it a deeper flavor. I did add a little dijon mustard...just abt 1/2 tsp at the end.  Whole family loved it, served it over thin pasta.  This would also be good with some thin aspargus thrown in at the last few minutes, we realized  this as we had it on the side this time.

text:
One of my very favorite recipes, from this site, or anywhere! We make this at least once a month, and I'm getting ready to make it tonight. 

I double the sauce ingredients, because it's so good, but I think dredging the chicken in flour is totally unnecessary.  I'm not a huge mushroom fan, so I just use a slotted spoon, and put them all on my husband's plate.

We serve it over a side of pasta, tossed with a litle garlic, olive oil and Parmesan.

Seriously delicious!

text:
Delicious! Both of my kids devoured this dish. The 7 year old (who likes his food bland) did not care for the sauce, but the 4 year old loved it. The nice thing about this dish is that you can serve the chicken with or without sauce depending on the tastes of your table. I ate mine with both the sauce and mushrooms and it was wonderful! Also loved how easy and fast this dish was to prepare. I followed recipe except I didn't dredge in flour - seemed unnecessary. It was so yummy, I don't think it needs the flour coating (or the time and mess to apply it).

text:
I loved this one!  My kids weren't keen on the mushrooms as I expected, but they could pick through them, which meant more for me!  As others did, I reduced the amount of vinegar to just over 1/8 cup and added a bit more broth as I was cooking 5 chicken breasts.  I also pounded the chicken so it was even thickness.  This recipe doesn't require a lot of prep (especially when you buy pre-washed & sliced mushrooms) and can be made with ingredients I usually have on hand.  I will be making this one again for sure.

country:
None
text:
Amazing! This is recipe has become a staple at our house; one of my husband's favorite, and even my toddler devours it. It is delicious and fairly easy to make as it is written, but I have made the following modifications: I always chop my chicken into bite-size pieces so it cooks faster. Fresh mushrooms obviously are best (especially portabellas), but drained canned work just fine (and they're cheaper!). I also serve it over spaghetti noodles tossed in a bit of olive oil, Parmesan cheese, and a bit of Italian seasoning. If you are REALLY short on time, just use a box mix of Parmesan noodles.

text:
Made this for Valentine's Day dinner - hubby and I loved it!  I didn't add mushrooms as I don't like them (but may try them next time), but even without it, it was amazing!  I didn't think the vinegar flavor was dominant at all.  I used chicken breast tenderloins instead of whole breasts based on reviews about pounding them flat, etc.  I think this worked great but you should cut back on the simmering in the sauce for 3-5 minutes.  I served with roasted red potatoes as suggested, which was a nice complement.  I will definitely make it again!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
A little balsamic goes a long way, in my opinion. We liked it, but felt it was a little too sweet, and I will cut back on the balsamic next time. Also, I think simmering the chicken for 10 minutes after it already cooked on one side for 3, causes it to be over cooked. After flipping the chicken, I cooked it for another 2 - 3 minutes, then took it out of the pan, kept it warm on a plate, and made the pan sauce seperately....poured over chicken and there was plenty of flavor w/o the dredge/crust getting soggy in the pan. Will make this again; I'll just tweak it a little for our preference.

OMG! This was SOOO delicious! I thought the balsamic would be over powering and really come through, but all of the flavors blended so well together that it was just MAGIC! text:
This recipe is outstanding. It is quick & easy plus, the flavor of the mushroom gravy had delightfully tart, earthy flavors.    The overall tastes of this recipe is a bit different from the usual fare. So, I could serve this on a weekly basis, or I could use it like a baseball pitcher uses a "change up" pitch, just to keep my family form getting in the usual dinner rut.    Furthermore, it could easily be dressed up for a candlelit dinner. Maybe some spaghetti, on the side, mixed with parsley & topped with big shreds of parmesan cheese cut from an old potato slicer.    I don't make changes to recipes until I make them at least once, but this time all I had was canned mushrooms & it still came out fine.

country:
None
text:
This was absolutely phenomenal!! My entire extended family loved it, from our 22 month old son to my 89 year old grandma! I took the advice of several others and did the following: omitted the flour, sliced the chicken breasts into strips, used portobello mushrooms, added 1 1/2 teaspoons of cornstarch mixed with a little water to the sauce mixture to help thicken it and I also used 10 cloves of garlic. The sauce was still a bit too thin, so I may not have reduced it long enough..will try that next time. The chicken was so moist and flavorful and it was honestly so tender, you could cut it with a fork! Served with butter and garlic rice and fresh steamed broccoli. Yummy!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious and simple!  I wanted to make just enough for 2 people so I only used 2 chicken breasts.  Although many said to omit the flour, I did coat the chicken with flour and it came out great.  I kept the sauce proportions the same and even doubled the mushrooms!  When I removed the chicken from the sauce, I added a slurry (cornstarch and water) to the sauce to thicken it up a little bit.  Then I added the chicken back the pan and stirred everything together.  The taste, texture, etc. was divine.  This is great for a week night because it's fancier but also quick to make and most of the ingredients are ones that you would have on hand.

text:
I followed this recipe but made a couple of changes.  I used 1/2 cup of balsamic vinigar; 1 14-1/4 oz can of chic broth and a 4.5 oz jar of mushrooms with liquid.  I did not coat the chicken with flour but added 1 tbsp of corn starch in 1/2 cup water at the end to thicken.  It was delicious and my husband raved about it as well.  This will be on my list of favs.  Thanks for the inspiration.

VERRRRRY GOOD!   Once you make it, you've earned bragging rights over your  newly acquired superb high class chef skills! I didn't have chicken broth on hand... so I used a lipton chicken noodle soup pkg and strained the broth and discarded the noodles and it was just as good! I also didn't have any fresh mushrooms on hand... only canned and, again, FABOULOUS!   I can't wait to try it with all the RIGHT ingredients. Served with stuffing and peas. YUM-O.

My husband and I LOVED this recipe!  It will go into regular circulation in my meal plans.  I would only suggest it, however, if you are a big fan of balsamic vinegar and I would recommend spending the extra money to get a quality, aged balsamic. I served it with oven roasted potatoes and steamed asparagus.  Together, it was an incredible meal.

Seriously yummy!  Halved the amount of chicken the recipe calls for since it's just the two of us and a three year old. text:
Very good!  I fileted the chicken breasts and sauteed them for 5 minutes per side.  Next time I will use half olive oil and half butter for sauteeing.  I will also cook both sides of the chicken and then remove them and keep them warm while sauteeing the mushrooms, as they prevented the second side of the chicken from browning adequately.  I will return the chicken to the pan when adding the liquids.  The amount of vinegar was perfect!  I will continue to dredge the chicken in flour before cooking, as I feel that it adds that succulent texture that I'm looking for in this dish.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-06-06T20:11:13.317

This was fantastic!!! I am very picky...and find myself disappointed with many recipes on this site that people rate 5 stars.  This one is worthy of all 5 stars and then some!! userID:
577467
Display Name:
Adh0621
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
36
favoritesCount:
56
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good, but not spectacular.  Though my husband liked it. I think it verged on being really good but it is missing something.  I slightly increased the broth and vinegar and added 1-2 teaspoons of sugar to cut some of the vinegar as I suspected it would be a bit tart as is.  I also pounded the chicken becuase I like the tenderness of pounded chicken.  I omited the flour b/c no one said it worked here but used a lot of All Season on the plain chicken.

The cooking method is very similar to chicken marsala, where a seasoned flour dredging is then browned in butter.  I might try to do that next time.  I like the reduced vinegar and garlic flavor, but I have to agree with some others that it was a touch bland.  If you werent getting a mouthful of vinegar sauce the chicken was really mild tasting- almost boring.  I had to salt it up quite a bit after cooking.

There is a more savory similar dish that is Chicken Abdoo with soy sauce and vinegar which is worth looking at if you like this one.  But I am going to try next time to pound, dredge in seasoned salted flour, sautee in butter and maybe double the reduction sauce so you cant help but get it with each bite.  It was a little bit scarce after reducing this time.

I am going to try this again, but as written, Id say its a 3 star.  I think I would have been really unhappy with unpounded chicken as the flattened chicken was at least more exposed to the sauce during cooking.

text:
This was a GREAT recipe!!! I made this for dinner tonight and my husband, 16-year old picky nephew, and I LOVED IT!  I didn't make too many variations.  After reading the other reviews, I just totally skipped the step of flouring the chicken.  I just sauteed it with just the seasoning.  I added flour at the end to thicken the mushroom sauce ... worked great!  Also, I used chicken stock instead of chicken broth - stock is just a preference of mine.  Lastly, I added onion only because my family loves the taste of onion whenever garlic is in a recipe.  Other than that, this was perfect!!!!  Thanks for posting!

text:
I loved this and will make it again. It looks and tastes like gourmet. I served it with white rice. Just a couple of pointers: 1) this calls for 4 chicken breasts, and I think it means half breasts, not whole ones. 2)NEVER rinse mushrooms; just wipe them with a paper towel or a little brush -- they're like sponges and will bloat up and release the water during cooking. Maybe that's why some people complained about slimy chicken breasts?

text:
Mmmmm, this sauce is soooo good!  I made a pork tenderloin (guy's fave for his birthday) and used this sauce with it. Also, when I made it with chicken, I pounded the chicken breasts and I did dredge them.  I know some people mentioned that there was no point to the flour but I think it really helped keep the chicken moist.  Nothing worse than dry chicken. Also added cornstarch=water cause we like sauces a little thicker.
Update... made the sauce again but didn't have enough mushrooms so I sauteed some fresh green beans with the garlic and mushrooms and it came out absolutely amazing.  Husband couldn't stop talking about it.

text:
I love this chicken, it's one of my favorite recipes on this site. I love the vinegar flavor so I wouldn't change a thing. 
I usually double balsamic vinegar, chicken broth and seasonings to make lots of sauce I also add in 1/2 teaspoon of Italian seasoning and pound my chicken down to a 1/4" thick. It makes excellent Sandwiches on Italian bread with fresh mozzarella. I give this recipe 10 STARS.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Overall this was a good recipe.  I made a few personal preference changes.  I always, always pound chicken breast, it makes for a much more delicate texture and cooks more evenly.  I took the chicken out of the pan while the mushrooms were going and then added back when the vinegar and broth went in.  Chicken breast doesn't take that long to cook.  The simmering time was less than 10 minutes.  For the garlic, I only had 3 (but they were large) cloves.  Recipe didn't state whether to chop, mince, leave whole, so I just ran a knife through them a few times.  The end result was very good.  I will be making this again.

text:
WOW! This was AMAZING! Presentation is elegant! I used 1 can of mushrooms (drained) in place of fresh because it's what I had on hand. The breasts were rather thick (I could have pounded thin but didn't want to take the time) so they required a little longer cooking time, about 6 minutes per side and then 20 minutes simmering. We just LOVED this dish! Not too much garlic at all - the balsamic vinegar balanced the garlic nicely. I did use a tad more thyme than what it called for. SUPER! This one will go in with my favorites! Thanks for the post Colleen! Excellent!

text:
I sautéed the chicken using the flour and spices and then put them aside. I made the balsamic vinegar sauce in the pan with the flour bits and scraped it up. Once cooked down a few minutes I poured the sauce over the chicken and served. That eliminates the flour from getting gooey on the chicken.

text:
This is a great recipe and one that I've made several times.  I cut the chicken down into thinner equal pieces to cook evenly (and I don't like thick meaty chicken).  I also followed the advice of others and did not bread the chicken.  

I added more mushrooms (a variety), I omitted the bay leaf (b/c I didn't have it), and used fresh thyme.  

Delicious!  

I served it with basmati rice and a side salad.  

My 3 kids (ages 7, 5, and 2) loved it plus my husband. Makes great left overs too.

text:
This dish was delish!  Super easy and simple to make. I had all the ingredients on hand but the mushrooms.  So I made it with out and it was still great! I used my cast iron braiser and it cooked perfect.  I love vinegar so I make it with a 1/2 cup and a whole can of broth.  I also added a tablespoon of honey to help with the tang. Served with roasted rosemary potatoes and broccoli, it was the perfect weeknight meal. Some people leave out the flour, but that helps thicken the sauce while it's reducing.

I made this recipe for Christmas Eve - served it with a basic risotto and green beans and it was great. I scaled it up in size to feed 6 and no problem. I pre-pound my boneless skinless chicken breasts when I bring them home and freeze individually for quick thaw and quick cooking. I used these which makes for nice even cooking time but that was my only "change" to the recipe. Made as directed and it turned out beautifully - so yummy and everyone enjoyed it. Some people might think that the flavour will be strong with so much basalmic but it is lovely. Enjoy and thank you for the submission. Always love to try new chicken recipes on my family.

Display Name:
lisaviolet

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was easy and delicious!  I used 1 shallot and 4 cloves of garlic.  I also did not dredge the chicken in flour, but instead whisked some flour in toward the end (like gravy).  I also added Epicure's Pasta Seasoning (although it's perfectly tasty without it); it just added even more flavour.
And it's much yummier on potatoes than pasta (because the potatoes soak up that yummy sauce better).  And, I added a little more butter (3 tbsp) and more chicken broth (1.25 cups) than called for just to make more sauce.  This sounds like a lot of altering, but it's just tweaks to my taste.  The recipe really is very tasty on it's own!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was missing a few things...particularly garlic and the bay leaf.  We enjoyed the flavors, even without those ingredients.  However, I only had 3 chicken breasts and the amount of sauce was just about perfect. I don't think it would be enough for 4 breasts, as the recipe was written.  Additionally, the sauce was quite runny - I would have preferred it a bit thicker (maybe a bit of cornstarch dissolved in broth).  Finally, the sauce was pretty vinegary.  This was fine over the chicken, but I really love sauces and would not have enjoyed it in excess (which I didn't have because the recipe did not make much) because of the vinegar.

Still, it was pretty simple to make (I did pound the chicken with a cast iron skillet like some other reviewers) and pretty tasty.  I would definitely make it again, but increase the amount of sauce just a bit.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is quite forgiving, and easily customized to suit your own tastes. I use at least a pound of mushrooms, and a full 15 oz. can of Swanson broth for the sauce, thickening it at the end with a little cornstarch. I like to serve this over a bed of thyme infused rice cooked in water and chicken broth. I've done the chicken with and without flour and had great results either way. The extra sauce I end up with mixes great into the rice!  I'm sure it would work with pasta or potatoes just as well. I also like steamed broccoli or asparagus as a veggie side. Delicious, simple, and even a little elegant. Great for a casual dinner with a couple of guests, or a weeknight family meal. Thanks for a great recipe!

I rarely coock for my boyfriend for two reasons 1) anyone you ask will tell you his mom is an awesome cook, as in she can heat up water and it taste delicious, great coock and 2) because of his mother being such a great cook he's a picky eater.... but when I prepared this recipe for him he LOVED it. I recommend it to anyone wherther you are a beginner or a experienced cook!

My son and I tried this for the first time tonight and we loved it.  I used suggestions from other reviewers and they worked well.  I didn't dredge the chicken in flour, using 1 Tbsp flour in the sauce to thicken it instead.  I also didn't have thyme so I left it out.  The only Balsamic I had was Raspberry Balsamic and it was WONDERFUL in this sauce.  I only used 2 chicken breasts and I pounded them flatter then served the chicken and sauce over linguini.  I would double the sauce ingredients for 4 breasts, to have enough.  Will make again and pass it on.

text:
This was a very good recipe.  Very elegant.    I followed the instructions exactly the first time and there wasn't enough sauce for us (we are sauce people).  The next time I doubled the vinegar and broth.  The flour didn't add much to the coloring so it is a take or leave it step.  I have served it with pasta and with rice.  It is good with either.  I did cook the rice with chicken stock and it was a nice compliment to the dish.  I didn't rinse the mushrooms as I have always been told not to put mushrooms underwater as they will soak in the water.  If they need it, I wipe them off with a damp paper towel.

This recipe is great and very easy! I followed the recipe to a T excluding the flour. Some of the reviews recommended using less balsamic vinegar. text:
Simple and delicious!  I made it as is, and it was great.  I will make a few changes next time, but not many. 1)  I will probably skip the flour on the chicken - it didn't really add much and, as noted by others, it did make it a little slimy. 2) I'll brown the chicken on both sides, remove it from the pan and deglaze with the broth/vinegar.  Then I'll add back the chicken and put in the mushrooms. 3)  Double the sauce and mushrooms.  I served the chicken with pasta, and there wasn't enough to drizzle over the pasta and chicken for all 4 servings.

text:
SUPERB!!! I skipped the flour, as other reviewers did.   For reviewers who though the sauce was too watery... you didn't let it reduce enough!! It should be like a GLAZE! I let it reduce for about 10 minutes, and the result was a thick, balsamic-y glaze. I felt like there wasn't enough glaze at the end though. So, I just threw in the same amounts of balsamic, broth, butter and a bit of thyme as called for in the recipe along with 1 clove of garlic and voila- I had more delicious tasting sauce. This is a keeper!

This was a fairly easy recipe, which I followed exactly. I have to disagree with the majority of reviewers and say that I wouldn't skip dredging the breasts in flour (which I seasoned), simply because the flour thickens the sauce slightly and gives the chicken a crispy outside. I cooked the sauce down for about 15 minutes to concentrate the flavors and served over angel-hair pasta.

text:
This was wonderful!  I'm organizing meals for a friend this week, and one of our friends who was cooking said she was making this.  She pointed me here when I asked for the recipe, and we decided to make it tonight.  Not disappointed!  Notes: 1. I used more garlic than called for (probably 10 cloves?) and will probably use even more next time.  My garlic wasn't perfectly fresh, though, so probably 10 really fresh cloves would be ok.  2. I will double the sauce next time.  There wasn't enough - it was delicious!  3.  I served it over fettuccine.  4.  I didn't use mushrooms (not a fan), just fyi for others who don't like mushrooms and might wonder if the recipe works without them.  Yes, it does!!  :)  Thanks for sharing, colleenlora!

userID:
4087965
Display Name:
FitzFamily

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a delicious and simple recipe, one you might expect to see on the menu of a good restaurant. After reading the suggestions of a few others, I decided to alter just some of the steps. I marinated the chicken a few tablespoons of vinegar and olive oil hours before preparing the meal, browned it for about 12 minutes, added the garlic/mushrooms/asparagus for another 3-5 minutes, then removed the chicken to a baking dish covered with foil before adding the vinegar and broth to the pan. I also added a small amount of corn starch and 1/4 cup cream to the mix and continued simmering until the asparagus was just right. Served the chicken over pasta drizzled with olive oil and more minced garlic and a touch of salt/pepper. I topped the whole thing with the vegetables and sauce from the pan. This method seemed to solve the "slimy chicken" some others experienced because it had been removed from the pan before adding the vinegar and broth. I strongly suggest anyone go ahead and use the flour mixture to coat the chicken (unlike what others suggested) as it definitely enhances the outcome of the entire dish and helps to contain the juices in the chicken. Just a few minor changes in the order of the original recipe and what an amazing dish!!!

A few things i did after reading a lot of the reviews: I marinated the chicken in chicken broth, enough to cover the breasts and then also put in 1/8 cup of Balsamic Vinega, and let sit for an hour. This made a HUGE difference in the flavor of the chicken. I only made 2 chicken breasts and i doubled the sauce, i should have tripled it, i had JUST enough for 2 servings. I cooked everything according to the exact times on the recipe and the chicken was so moist! At the end, i added 4 TB of heavy cream, to thicken up the sauce and i also lightened up the color. I served this over whole wheat penne pasta....tasted like something you would get at a fine Italian restaurant! This will definitely be a favorite of mine!!

(as per other reviews I opted for the cornstarch slurry to thickjen the sauce). I also skipped the flour.

alsnwndrln

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a GREAT recipe! We love going to BJs and they make a wonderful balsamic chicken so I made a few changes to make it like that. First I didn't bread the chicken. I also omitted the mushrooms. (I love mushrooms, that just isn't where I wanted to go with this.) I cooked the sauce as is, other than that. After the balsamic reduction was done, I took thin slices of red onion and placed them in the pan that the chicken and sauce had been in. I added some more balsamic, some more chicken broth, and about a tablespoon of sugar. I cook them until they are tender. Then I place some fresh spinach on the plate, add a dollop of mashed potatoes, a chicken breast, and then the onion with balsamic reduction drizzle on the top. The presentation is beautiful and the taste is amazing.

This was amazing! I will be adding this to our regular dinner rotation. I made a few changes. I used one large chicken breast half and sliced it in half so I had two thin pieces of chicken. I skipped the flour and butter. I increased chicken broth to 1 cup. Increased dried thyme to 1/2 tsp. Used 1/2 tsp. cornstarch to thicken things up a bit. Served over jasmine rice cooked in chicken broth and sweet peas on the side. Both my husband and I agreed that this was one excellent dinner!

text:
I know this sounds harsh when compared to other reviews.  Let me explain.  3 stars for me means I would try this recipe again, hoping to find the right modifications to make it work for us.  That is to say this recipe is inspirational but doesn't quite work for us as is and I'm a little stumped as to how to fix it. But... I'm willing to give it another try because there was a lot that worked with it.  4 stars means good as is with little or no modification.  5 stars means my whole family wants this recipe any day, anytime. In other words, a 5 star rating is a 'boo-ya'!  This recipe is a 3 star for us, and that's a good thing.  I was very impressed with how incredibly tender and moist the chicken came out.  Also, it was easy and fast, also a plus.  On the minus side, the vinegar over-powered the dish and I am a lover of balsamic vinegar.  I will try this recipe again, perhaps adding some red wine and/or cream to mellow out the vinegar.  Give it a try.  It's worth it.  Perhaps someone more knowledgeable than I will have a suggestion for mellowing out the vinegar?

Rating:

dateLastModified:
2009-09-11T14:04:44.22
helpfulCount:

userID:
2252315
Display Name:
Madame Jarrin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
76
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/918091.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good, but if you go too far with the balsamic, you could easily just end up with balsamic chicken. It will have the tendency to override the delicate herbs completely.   If using bouillon instead of broth, use NO salt and cut even further back on the balsamic. Also, I doubled the thyme and bay to counter the bouillon saltiness, as well as using a bit more water to dilute it a bit.   The flour, I put in at the very end using a little sieve, tapping a bit here and then a bit there and stirring it in without lumps. I think I used about a tablespoon all told. A little goes a long way.  I cooked oyster mushrooms that I had cut long and thin (to resemble noodles) separately in 4 tablespoons of melted butter, a 1/4 cup white wine and 1 crushed clove of garlic and used that as the foundation instead of noodles as shown in the photo. It made for an interesting change from the same old same old noodle/rice/potatoes routine. And the earthy tones balanced the sharpness of the chicken nicely.   I served this dish with gingered carrots & dates (found on allrecipes) and we drank a Provençal rosé. I will be making this meal again in the future. Bon apetit!

text:
This is a FANTASTIC dish! I have made it several times already since I found the recipe a month ago. I use 2 chicken breasts instead of 4 (there are only 2 of us eating it). Be careful - follow the quantities in the recipe and the timing, regardless if you are using less chicken. The last time that I made the chicken, I followed the timing to a T and the chicken was moist and fully cooked. Previous times I had adjusted the quantities of liquid and the length of cooking time - chicken turned out dry and not enough sauce.

text:
Absolutely amazing!  Made this recipe and followed it to a tee - apart from cutting the garlic down to 3 cloves instead of 6.  Amazing and I am definitely going to cook it again.  Make sure you use high quality balsamic vinegar when making this though, it makes a world of difference!  The sauce really thickened up and didn't taste vinegary at all.  I made linguine pasta to go with the chicken and it really went well, the sauce stuck to the pasta well and tasted delicious - in fact it was one of the nicest pasta sauces I've ever tasted!!!  A really good recipe that is easy to do, doesn't have a million ingredients and tastes like a restaurant quality meal.  Thanks for sharing.

My only change was omitting the flour, then adding a slurry (cornstarch/water) near the end instead of reducing the sauce. I used baby bella shrooms, fat free low sodium broth, and served over wild/white rice. Even my 14mo ate everything.

text:
If you are a onion lover like me, you can add some sliced onions to the initial stage of the recipe, where you are sauteeting your garlic. I have made this, my way, for quite an array of tastes(and personalities), and every single one of them has said it was great. I have even omitted the garlic and used a combination of onions and leeks with satisfying results, but I really think the onions and garlic is the best combination. Watch the time! This dish is best when the chicken is just done.

text:
This is a fantastic dish!  I agree with other reviewers, this tastes like restaurant quality.  After reading so many of the reviews, I couldn't understand how such a quick dish, with a few basic ingredients, could come together so nicely.  I used chicken breasts I had flattened at the butcher and it came out so tender that the meat was falling apart as I was plating it. I added thinly sliced white onion as it was cooking and used cornstarch dissolved in water to thicken it slightly.  Aside from that, I stuck to the recipe.  I served this with buttered and seasoned egg noodles.  This is an incredibly rich tasting dish.  My husband and I both loved it.  I will definitely make this again, especially for company when we're entertaining.

text:
Both my husband and son enjoyed this recipe.  There were a couple of changes I made, and I will make more for next time.
I used minced garlic instead of cloves.  No problem there.  I served it over spaghetti--but with that there wasn't enough juice.

Next time:  add more chicken broth.  Use salted broth or lightly salt chicken.  I'll reduce the cooking time of the chicken--it was a little overdone by keeping it warm while reducing the sauce.  

Because of the quick cooking time and the wonderful flavor, we will use this again.

text:
this was excellent. I love balsamic vinegar in my recipes. After reading the debates to flour or not to flour the chicken, I went down the middle. I used an extremely light dusting. It was just enough to put some body in the sauce and reducing at the end was key. When I first put the liquid ingredients together, I saved about 1/4C and used it on chicken shish kabobs as a marinade and and about 3T for basting. Was great there too, really enhanced the vegetables. Next time, I am going to make it using beef broth and smother a couple of beef filets with it! You have got to try this one.

text:
Definitely a 5 star recipe! I started cooking with balsamic vinegar a few months ago as a way to flavor enhance in an attempt to cut other additions that added calories. This is a quick and easy recipe.
I'm not a mushroom eater so I left them out. I did flour the tops of the chicken but will probably leave it out as I don't think it will take anything away from the flavor. I cut the recipe in half since I cook for one, but from now on will make the sauce in the full amount. I believe my suace cooked down faster as my stovetop runs a little hot! I also left out the butter at the end, didn't need it. I did use what sauce I did have mixed in with new potatoes I roasted.Thanks for the recipe! Chicken always needs a boost!

text:
This was very tasty and had a good mix of flavors.  My 2 and 4 yr olds even ate it.  I did have to make some adjustments (based on what I had in the house)  Since I had no mushrooms or onions I used 1/2 can of diced tomatoes (garlic, basil and oregano flavored) drained and a can of water chestnuts (drained).  I really liked the tomatoes in it (will use those again!) and the water chestnuts absorbed the flavors and gave it crunch--but next time I think I'll try the mushrooms.  I used dried rosemary instead of Thyme.  And I added in 2 tsps. of heavy cream at the end, as some reviewers suggested.  Used 10 cloves of garlic, which was great.  Also, had to use 1 cube of chicken bullion in 1 cup water instead of chicken broth.  But even with my forced substitutions this came out great! Nice easy, basic recipe to play around with.  Served over basmati rice and it was a hit! I will definitely make again--only will make more sauce as it disappeared fast.

Followed the recipe & would only make the following change. Says to remove chicken and keep warm. I accidently left a portion of chicken in the sauce as it was reducing. I found that this portion had MUCH more flavor than the rest after I pulled it out of the oven and poured the sauce on it. Next time, I'll leave all of the chicken to simmer in the sauce instead of removing it. Otherwise - very good dish.

text:
This was delicious!! I was thinking ahead and pulled up this website around noon.(love this site)  That gave me time to marinate my chicken.  I too omitted flouring it, but did add a couple squeezes of my balsamic vinaigrette salad dressing.(then only add a tiny bit of balsamic vinegar to sautee) After marinating about 2hrs, I simply sauteed the marinated chicken from the bag for a few minutes,, before adding the remaining marinade mixture from the bag.  I flipped it a few times and it was perfectly juicy after about 15 minutes. *MAKE SURE THE MARINADE BOILS A FEW MINS* We personally enjoyed it with pasta, but any starch would fit; very versitile! Thanks!!

text:
Nothing wrong with this one! Very good!  I did add a bit of extra liquid (as others mentioned)but still let it reduce.  I can understand other reviewers who were not thrilled with the basalmic vinegar.  If basil and/or vinegar are not on your favourites list then this is not for you.  I too, pounded out two chicken breasts and had plenty to serve three. I did the chicken first, put it aside, then the garlic, mushrooms(and some sweet onion, added the liquid and put the chicken back in. Don't belittle the bay leaf and thyme, they DO add flavour!  Thanks Colleen, this is going in my book.

This recipe is awesome! I'm always looking for ways to kick up chicken breast and this definitely did the trick. This dish is SO flavorful! The only modifications I made was I added 1 cup of chicken broth as opposed to 3/4 cups. I also added the garlic to the pan just a minute or so before I added the broth and balsamic because I was afraid the garlic would burn. My husband and even my 16 month old loved it. This recipe will definitely become a standard in my household.

I wish I could add more stars. This is a truly delicious recipe. I prepared as directed, although I did marinate the breasts in balsamic vinegar, salt & pepper before coating with flour. text:
This was really good!  I pounded the chicken thin, marinaded it with balsamic vinegar and garlic powder for about 10 minutes before dredging it in the flour.  I only used 3 cloves of garlic, but I pressed them through a garlic press first.  I only used 1/8 Cup of the vinegar at first, but after I removed the chicken, I put more into the pan.  I used 1 cup of chicken broth and omitted the bay leaf.  Served it over polenta...mmm mmm good!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/121.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an incredible dish! I, too, am tired of cream soup chicken recipes and was looking for a fresher tasting, and less fatty, recipe. I followed the suggestion of some other reviewers to cut down on the vinegar, but later wished I'd used the full 1/4 cup -- I enjoyed the tanginess and thought it could have been a bit more so.  Didn't have fresh mushrooms, so used canned, and kept thinking how much better the dish would have been with fresh mushrooms. As others have said, there's not quite enough sauce. I ended up using the whole can of chicken broth at the end when cooking down the sauce, and would have even liked a bit more sauce. The sauce was a wonderful marriage of tangy and savory, and was perfect on the chicken, and on the brown rice I made as a side dish.

text:
Per other comments, I left out the "dredge in flour" step (one less dirty dish!).  The recipe is very tart, so if you like a mellower flavor, cut back the balsamic vinegar for sure.  I ended up adding cornstarch to thicken the sauce since I didn't have time to reduce it, and it was delicious and just the right consistency. Will definitely make again, but with a little less balsamic.

It wouldn't be fair for me to rate this any less than five stars because I screwed up which caused the chicken to be dry, but i followed the recipe for the reduction/sauce to a tee and it ended up absolutely delicious. First reduction I've ever done, easy peasy. However, I did find that the reduction was done well before the 7 mins the recipe stated. (The chicken hadn't defrosted before I was ready to make this for dinner so I ended up having to poach it for a bit and then finished it per the recipe. Poached it a bit too long so I wound up over cooking it. Totally not the recipe's fault.)

Hubby made per directions except used half the balsamic vinegar. It was still strong enough for balsamic flavor. We will try just cooking the chicken w/flour, salt & pepper until done. When all is cooked then we'll add the chicken without covering it so it doesn't get soggy.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious but I did make a couple changes/additions.  First change was after I did the flour breading, I put it in the refrigerator for a little bit to let firm up.  The breasts I had were double the normal size so I browned them for double the time on each side.  I think the key to making the coating not gummy is to make sure your heat is high enough.  I added some onions and carmelized them along with the mushrooms.  Now, everyone said the amount of balsamic was too much but I actually ended up adding a little more.  I let the breasts braise for 20 minutes instead of 10 and cooked the sauce down for longer too.  Even still, I really don't think this was too far off of the original recipe and  I WILL make it again!

text:
This was very good. I did make a few minor changes. Instead of thyme and a bay leaf,  I used Italian seasonings and parsley. I also added sauteed sweet onions and red bell pepper. After I browned the chicken, I removed it from the pan then sauteed the mushrooms, onions and bell pepper. Then I put the balsamic vinegar in with chicken broth and put the chicken back I  the pot. Simmered for 10 minutes uncovered and voila. Next time I will double the sauce because it does cook out while thickening. I served it with curly pasta (I forget the exact name).

Display Name:
whachagotcooking

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4284648.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an easy, fast and delicious recipe. I did read many of the reviews and followed some great suggestions. 1. I did not coat the chicken in flour as many reviewers said it was not necessary and I have to agree with them. The chicken still came out tender and moist. 2. At least half of the reviews I read suggested using less balsamic vinegar. One reviewer used heavy cream to tone down the tartness of the vinegar and a few other reviewers followed suit and they loved how the recipe turned out. I made 2 batches. I added 2 tablespoons of heavy cream to the first batch to tone down the tartness of the vinegar. It did make a difference and it still came out pretty scrumptious. The second batch of chicken I made was without the heavy cream and just the 1/4 cup balsamic vinegar as indicated in the recipe.That too came out really delicious, succulent and well, not bland. 3. Also, I used chicken stock instead of broth. This really can make a difference in any recipe. It adds a richness and just takes a dish to that next level. Great recipe and thanks for sharing! Thank you to all the reviewers out there! Your comments are always appreciated by those of us who love too cook!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
This was such a hit with my husband and me and healthy! Makes a great mid-week dish and would be great to impress company too. I made it just as described and it came out great. The only thing I ran into was that my 4 chicken breast were huge and my pan wasn't big enough to make them all at the same time. I had to reserve some broth and vinegar to cook the rest. Next time, I would use smaller breasts or double the ingredients to accommodate a second batch.  Oh, and I used already seasoned pan searing flour. So easy.

Bman39

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a good dish and my wife loved it. After reading some of the reviews, I made a few changes to enhance the flavors. I used 2  bone in chicken breast halves  & cut them in half. I took the skin off & seasoned thyme, salt, and pepper. I thinly sliced the garlic cloves, used cremini & bottom mushrooms. I also added 1 tbsp. of dried shallots. I had some raspberry balsamic vinegar reduction in the frig so I used that instead of regular balsamic. Because the breast contained the bone, I cooked for 15 min. instead of 10 with the  mushrooms and broth with a pinch of cayenne pepper. I was tempted to reduce the vinegar by a 1/4 cup and make up the
difference with white wine to reduce the sweetness.

text:
I didn't have a bay leaf & I did omit the flour, but added some corn starch to the juices at the end to thicken it up as I almost doubled the chicken stock, oops.  I was a bit distracted so I'm not positive about my cooking times being right on, but it was a smidge dry, however we are talking boneless skinless chicken breasts here & aren't they almost always dry?  Anyway, it was a quick & easy dinner for us, served with green beans, carrots & roasted potatoes.  My husband likes to tell us what he'd pay for the meal if we were in a restaurant & he placed this one at 26.99.  (I wouldn't pay more than 17.99 personally.) But it went over well with both my kids, who love mushrooms, and my resident food critic.

text:
This  is a nice, simple recipe.  I made it with dried shiitake mushrooms which I soaked, then sliced like matchsticks.  I used the soaking "broth" instead of the chicken broth.  After tasting the almost-finished sauce, I added a small spoonful of sugar, to tone down the vinegar taste (I did use a good balsamic, but it just tasted strong, even with reducing the measure).  Then, per another reviewer's suggestion, I added a small spoonful of a spicy mustard.   Served over brown rice; husband liked it.  Thanks for posting.

userID:
16525623
Display Name:
Redcaddy97
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm quite surprised that I was disappointed with this recipe.  When I read it, I just knew that I would love it.   We love the flavor of balsamic vinegar and use a better quality balsamic  often.  I basically followed the recipe as-is with some very minor changes.  I had two pretty large skinless breasts.  Rather than pound them out as some others suggested, I cut them in two horizontally making 4 pieces.  I doubled the sauce at the suggestion of other reviewers.   I left off the dredging flour since it seemed that a good number of reviewers found it better without. 

From there, followed exactly and wound up with a sweet but very vinegary sauce.   I had seen that others had halved the balsamic, but I figured that they must be non-balsamic lovers.  Served it with angel hair and sauteed spinach. 

Well, next time, I'm going to try halving the balsamic. I did decide to save out about half of the sauce (with two of the halved breast halves) and tried adding a good glug of heavy cream.   Eating as leftovers, the cream did cut a good bit of the acidity and was actually quite good.  Again, next time, I think that if I cut the balsamic in half, everything will be fine.   Thanks for the recipe...it's given me a good place to start!

text:
This was a really good recipe! I followed the directions exactly, except I was maybe a bit generous with the vinegar. I did double the sauce because it turns out that I don't have a pan big enough for 4 chicken breasts so I made it in batches of 2 breasts at a time. I didn't double the mushrooms though and maybe I should have. I bought pre sliced mushrooms, 8 oz of them. Also I don't think I reduced the sauce enough as it was super watery, so perhaps I would add some corn starch next time. Overall this was a really good recipe I wouldn't hesitate to make for guests!

text:
Good! and pretty quick & easy. Sauce reduction is nice  - make twice the sauce it calls for because it's good over noodles or mashed potatoes and reduces down quickly even with the lid on. I had to add more liquid after the chicken was done to turn the paste back into sauce. Chicken got a bit overcooked - take it out of the pan when it hits 160oF and tent under foil. Consider brining it for 30 minutes to retain moisture.

1622831
Display Name:
lostlittlefairy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/75970.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read a lot of the reviews prior to making this. I was worried would be too vinegary tasting but it turned out great and savory. I followed most of the recipe with a few tweaks based on my own family's preferences and notes from reviewers.



A few things I did take note of was that lots of reviewers skipped the flouring part. I was tempted but decided to just lightly sprinkle the flour on the chicken to crisp it some during the frying process. The rest of the flour I reserved for later so I wouldn't end up with slimey chicken. 

I also noted one reviewer said she went for a higher end balsamic vinegar. I decided to do the same. I've never worked with balsamic vinegar before but my end result wasn't vinegary. I didn't have the bite that everyone was talking about. I will say I will continue to do the same for this recipe since just a few extra dollars results on a large bottle. I also put in 1/2 tsp of mustard powder to give it a different dimension of flavor.

With the chicken broth, I increased it to 1.25 cups instead for more sauce and to tone down any potential vinegary taste. When it was done, I poured an additional 1/4 cup of broth in a small bowl to mix with the remaining flour. Once that mixture was mixed smooth, I slowly poured it into the sauce stirring the whole time. It thickened the sauce up to just the right consistency. 




The end result was a very smooth sauce that was mild and savory all at once. I paired mine with linguine noodles and a salad (green leaf
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2015-11-15T14:21:54.173
helpfulCount:
0

text:
I followed the recipe exactly including the flour and used the amount of chicken, garlic, mushrooms to suit my appetite and taste. I halved the sauce ingredients. I like anything vinegar, but am not terribly keen on balsamic, as for me it is too sweet. However I always have a bottle in the larder and so used it. I enjoyed it, but it was just on the verge of being too sweet and therefore inedible.  It is a simple recipe and quite pleasant, but next time I will either use other vinegar, or mix balsamic with other vinegar.

text:
As written I give this 4.5 stars.  I wanted to try it exactly as shown first.  There were suggested changes that really should be done.  First, flouring the chicken is out.  It definately made the finished product kinda mushy.  I will use a white balsamic next time, as suggested because the color is a little off-putting.  

You will know when the balsamic has reduced.  Do not keep cooking at this point or the sauce becomes a little goopy.  I kept cooking because the time was not done.  

The sauce was wonderful and I will actually triple it the next time.  This cooked up fast and was super yummy.  I served it over rice pilaf.

Just made this tonight. It was very good. I took the advice of several reviewers and did not dredge the chicken in flour because of the time that it's covered during cooking. I didn't use enough mushrooms though. I bought an  8 oz. package of sliced mushrooms and thought it would be plenty - I was wrong! Next time I'll get at least a pound! Oh, I also used 1/4 teaspoon Old Bay seasoning and left out the bay leaf (I forgot that I didn't have any). Worked out great! Thank you for this recipe.

text:
Pounded out the chicken breast, seasoned w/salt and peper, as well as seasoning the flour. After browning the chicken removed it from the pan, then added in chopped onion, garlic and mushrooms. Followed the recipe as far as amounts of balsamic and broth, but in addition added 1/2 cup white wine. simmered sauce for about 10 minutes, then added chicken back in, cooked for additional 15 minutes along with rosemary, a bit more salt and bay leaf, didn't swirl in the butter at the end. Served with angel hair and roasted broccoli, Very good, the whole family enjoyed!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is simply FANTASTIC! I have made this over five times already, which means it's a keeper. I sauteed the chicken with minced onion and fried garlic, then added the chicken broth and balsamic vinegar. Here's my variations to the sauce: I added about 2 cups of fresh diced tomatoes (to thicken and enhance the flavor), and about 1 cup of diced mango (it adds a really nice and sweet flavor to the sauce). I set the chicken aside, and simmered the sauce for about 20 mins before tossing the chicken back in. The result is a very tangy and sweet balsamic vinegar chicken dish!!!

text:
All in all this was very good. Not spectacular, but very good. I used onions instead of mushrooms just because that is all I had on hand.  I left the vinegar, chicken broth ratio alone and thought it was great as written. No need to reduce the vinegar as some have said. Not at all vinegary. I did flour the chicken as the recipe stated which eliminated the need to thicken with flour or cornstarch as others did. Stick to the recipe as written. It needs no adjusting. I served this over brown rice.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm on the fence for this recipe. I was attracted to this because I love Balsamic Vinegar - I could practically bathe in it. But I was rather disappointed at how sweet it became with the garlic. I was expecting something savory and ended up adding plenty of fresh Parmesan to the sauce to give it a little more salt and substance.  Other than the sweetness, I loved this recipe. Very user friendly, it still tastes great for left overs (if you can manage to save any). I too forewent the flour on the chicken. I also fried another clove of garlic on the side for garlic-crisps which add a nice touch I think, as well as a welcomed crunch.
