text:
I made this last night and it was very good. Didn't flour the chkn because it browns so beautifully in EVOO. Added Wondra to sauce to thicken at end. A good basalmic vinegar has NO vinegar taste. It's one of those things where you get what you pay for. I increased the stock to a full cup & used 10 cloves of garlic like earlier posters. This would also be good with Marsala in place of the basalmic and a few capers too. Dry sherry or lemon juice would be worth a try also. Will experiment and report back. It's nice to find a simple, no-brainer recipe that is so tasty and so versatile. Thank you.

I do disagree with some of the other reviewers however---I did dredge the chicken in flour before cooking and thus I did not need to add any thickening agent and the chicken turned out wonderfully.  I also patted the chicken dry before dredging it.  I pounded the breasts first as well and also used 1 cup of chicken broth.  I served it with couscous.

text:
This was good, but lacking something.  I foured the chicken breast and fried them in some olive oil on both side to brown, the added the garlic and also a tbs of tomato pastelet the paste brown for a minute before adding the vingar and broth and let this reduce a bit before adding the chicken in to finish cooking.  This took about 4 minutes and by then the sauce was a perfect consistency. The chicken came out great, I think if you pan sear the floured chicken first it seals in the juice and alsoprevents the floury taste some are refering to.

text:
Excellent recipe. Very easy. I omitted the flour and used two pans for the 4 chicken breasts, adding garlic and mushrooms to each pan, and then consolidating into one pan after they were browned. A good move. The breasts browned beautifully and then all fit nicely into the pan with the broth/vinegar to simmer. Definitely has a vinegar kick, so if you're not a fan, this might not be the dish for you.

text:
I can't say enough great things about this recipe.  First off, I'm way more of a baker than a cook...and most of the dinners that I make that don't already come in a box end up coming out pretty poor..I'm fully ready to admit that.  Now that that's out in the open, this recipe was SUPER easy to follow.  I followed it to a T except I subbed rosemary for thyme.  Every step went off without a hitch and by the time I was done, I was super proud of myself, it looked and smelled great...but I had that one burning question left...did it taste good?  The answer is YES, it was delicious!  On par with something my husband might make, and he's a chef!  I highly recommend this recipe to anyone, but especially to the fumbling cook such as myself ;)  If you're a novice cook and need to make a dinner for guests-I'd say this is your #1 fool-proof guest pleaser!  Also great for any occasion though.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6633460.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good!  I used far more cloves of garlic - but only the small ones to the inside of two bulbs.  I also didn't have as many mushrooms as the recipe called for, and can't wait to try it out with the proper amount.  I did only make two chicken breast halves, not four . . . and followed the recipe for the sauce.  It was just barely enough for two.  If you are making this dish to serve 4, I would double the sauce part of the recipe.  We served this over white rice - it's what I had on hand.  Next time I'll try wild or brown rice.  I read a few reviews that said that they cut back on the vinegar, because of the flavor being too strong.  Also, some added a touch of cream to cut the vinegar flavor.  I didn't follow these recommendations and thought the sauces flavor was very good.  We did add some additional salt to our individual dishes, to our liking.

This is a seriously delicious entree. In fact, it was such a hit that I'm fixing it for the second time in as many weeks. I did follow some of the listed variations: 1. pounded the breasts to an even thickness 2. skipped the flour and 3. reduced the vinegar to 3T. I was concerned that the chicken might be tough; it seemed like a long cook time for a boneless chicken breast, but it was tender and delicious.

text:
one word - AWESOME! I just bought my first bottle of balsamic vinegar and I decided to try this recipe out. It was so juicy and delicious.  I did omitted some ingredients (flour and butter) though as so not to add on calories (I'm on a weight loss plan) and it still taste great!   I wanted to use button mushroom but didn't have any and so I used buna-shimeji and it was good!   I did a minor change to it. Instead of adding the garlic after you saute the chicken, I saute the garlic first, then only saute the chicken  I added cooked rice a few minutes before taking the pan off the stove. The rice would absorb the flavour from the sauce. Tasted good.  Anyway,this is a quick,easy and simple recipe. Good for the health conscious and those who are on a weight loss program

text:
Easy, Flavorful, and low in fat! I Grilled the chicken breast after I evened it out and dipped it in white wine, and took it out early from the sauce to keep it moist.  I used the same amount listed for the sauce but only 2 chicken breast halves, so I would double the sauce if I were to use 4 halves. i didn't have any thyme or bay leaves, so I used sage, and it still turned out good.  Added a teaspoon of honey to enhance the sweetness and thickness.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was yummy, but I made a few adjustments...I followed others' recommendations, and omitted dredging the chicken.  I seasoned and browned both sides, removed the chicken, sauteed mushrooms, garlic (2 cloves) and onions, scrapping up the browned bits.  I added the vinegar, about 1c. broth, bay leaves and tarragon because I had no thyme. I simmered for a few minutes, put the chicken back in to finish cooking.  removed them again, I found the sauce a little acidic, so I added more broth to dilute the vinegar, and flour (approx. 3 tbsp) and sour cream (about 1/2c.) to make it creamier. Tossed it with noodles and chicken and it was yummy! next time I`m going to use a little less vinegar.

country:
None
text:
This is one of the best recipes I have ever made on allrecipes!!! Absolutely scrumptious and incredibly easy! I too, left out the flour and simply browned the breast. I used bone-in chicken as it was on sale. After pulling out the chicken to thicken the sauce, I used a fork to pull the chicken meat from the bone. I then added the meat back into the thickened sauce. The other alteration was that I used red wine vinegar, owing to not having balsamic. The meat was juicy and tender, which made me so happy- despite all the yummy things I cook, my chicken has a habit of being like shoe leather, and horribly dry. But not anymore!!! The flavor was lovely. The husband and kids LOVED it~~~ Everyone ate 2 bowls, and are asking me to make it again very soon. Thank you, thank you, thank you, for this fabulous recipe!!! We've a new family favorite!

text:
This recipe was excellent!  I did change this a little bit.  I used turkey breasts because their leaner and diced them and threw them in the oil with the garlic and canned mushrooms (which was all I had on hand) then added the balsamic vinegar and let that cook in for about 30 secs and then added the broth and spices.  I sprinkled a bit of flour in afterwards to thicken the sauce.  Then after it was all done thickening sprinkled some chopped green onions on top!  Looks lovely and tastes even better.  Thanx for a wonderful but easy recipe :)

I made this as my first foray into using balsamic vinegar in cooking- I'm so glad I did! I made this first time around for my boyfriend & his Mom and a friend of his, and they gave it stellar reviews. The chicken was juicy & wonderfully flavored, and the juicy balsamic mushrooms were also delightful. I am currently making it now for my roommates- this is definitely going to become one of my staple dishes!

text:
Loved it! Not a big fan of balsamic vinegar so I used red wine vinegar. It was wonderful. I did flour the chicken breasts after pounding them a little and to the flour I added some garlic powder, and other seasonings. I doubled the amounts as I had a big package of chicken breasts and then had the left overs for lunch during the week. I did add a little chicken broth to the lunch containers so that the chicken would not dry out during reheating. A big 5 star winner. My family loved it.

region:

country:
None
text:
I followed the recommendations of others and left out the flour.  I used a spare amount of a salt/pepper seasoning mixture on the chicken prior to sauteeing the breasts, and I also pounded out the breasts to make them as flat as possible prior to cooking.  I also added diced red onion with crushed garlic since I only had about 1/2 lb of mushrooms.  I didn't reduce the sauce much at the end, and there was plenty left over for putting on top of mashed potatoes.  I used dried parsley and a bit of thyme for the seasoning in the sauce.  Very yummy and really easy to make!

text:
Let me begin by saying I am NOT a mushroom person, in fact the idea of me eating this was slightly repulsive. Well, turns out that I AM a mushroom lover with the right dish and this is definitely it! I thought I was crazy for making something I didn't think I would like, but I'm glad I did because this is one of the most interesting recipes I've made all month. The sauce was delicious and even though everyone said skip the flour, I didn't and liked the thin coating because it helped soak up some of the sauce. The chicken was nice and moist and I served it over pasta with asparagus. Delicious! Also, tasted good reheated which is important because I cook for myself only and always have leftovers. This one is going in my recipe book!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/47596.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was such an easy, yummy recipe! I always like to try the recipe as written first, but I only had 1/8th cup of balsamic vinegar and not enough fresh mushrooms, so I used one can in addition to the few fresh that I had. I'm definatley going to make this again, but with the full amount of vinegar and lot's of fresh mushrooms next time. The only thing I found I had to do was add a little flour to the sauce to thicken it slightly. I forgot the butter at the end, but it was still great without it. This is a keeper for sure! I noticed that many people were saying the flour on the chicken made it goopy - you literally just *dust* the chicken...pick it up in your hands and pat the excess flour off - you aren't supposed to thickly coat it or it will end up that way. Try this recipe...you won't be disappointed!

This recipe was good.  I didn't have the same problem with the flour that others seemed to have; I just made sure the flour wasn't thick, I barely dusted the chicken with it.  I didn't have a bay leaf, but the thyme worked just fine. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It is one of the best recipes here and it's easy!!!  I didn't have any bay leaf or tyme on hand and it still turned out flavorful.  I followed the recipe exactly and the flour worked out great.  I suggest that you make sure your chicken is pat dried and seasoned.  I used all seasoned salt and peppers.  Then let it sit for a few minutes before you dredge the chicken through the flour.  Make sure it's not clumping.  If the flour clumps on the chicken your sauce will too.  Brown it and follow the recipe as directed.  If you don't like the tartness you can add half a tablespoon or either brown sugar or regular sugar to offset the tartness.  Enjoy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a fun and very delicious dish to make. I did everything as written except that I used boneless chicken thighs instead of breast meat, thigh meat always seems to turn out moister for me.  I only browned the thighs for about 2 minutes max on each side, pulled them out, sauteed the mushrooms and garlic, then added the thighs back in with the broth and vinegar, and spices,  to simmer for 20 minutes on a low simmer.  They turned out perfect.  I almost missed the end step of reducing the sauce down, then adding butter at the end, I am so glad I did this, the sauce turned out great.  I will make again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
EXCELLENT! The sauce is great on STEAK too....especiall filets!  Prepare the sauce following the recipe exactly as the recipe calls for...only omitting the chicken and flour.  Prepare your steaks separately from the sauce!  Salt & pepper each side of your steak and then sprinkle about 1/2 tsp sugar on each side as well (for browning).  Pan sear for 1 minute on each side.  Then put in pre-heated oven (325) for 15-30 minutes depending on the thickness and your preferred doneness.  For more details on this method, please see the article on this site entitled, "Great Steak - How to Cook for a Crowd".  These come out FABULOUS every time.  My dad and hubby think these are much better than any steak at any restaurant!

A delicious meal!  Make sure you watch the sauce as it's simmering (when it is covered).  I turned my back to wash a couple dishes while my sauce was simmering, and I turned to find my sauce had splattered out of the pan and made a little mess around the stovetop!  Oops.  :P  Luckily I caught it in time before all my sauce ended up on the counter.  I really liked the garlickiness of the sauce(I probably added more than required) and the mushrooms were perfect.  I only wish I had some more to add!  I served the chicken with steamed rice and a mixture of steamed veggies.  Simple but flavorful meal.

I really loved this recipe. I can't believe people cut the vinegar in half! I used all of it and it still turned out much more subtle than I thought it would. I may even increase it next time. For the garlic, I crushed 5 of the cloves and minced 1. I will probably mince at least half next time, it definitely wasn't overpowering and could have used a bit more kick to it. text:
I made this in my oven because I broke the lid of my crockpot just as I was ready to put everything in!  I made the recipe as written except that I added about 2 1/2 cups of chicken broth plus a little white wine that I used to deglaze the pan I browned the chicken in. I expected more evaporation in my oven casserole than in the crockpot, but I should have used at least 4 cups of liquid because the sauce reduced down to a very intense but delicious 1/3 cup.  I used the juice of half a lemon plus an extra squeeze from the other half and it was perfect.  I baked it in a covered casserole at 325 degrees for 3 hours.  I will try this again in my oven with more liquid and the mushrooms some other reviewer suggested.

text:
Yum, Yum, Yummy!  I was planning on making Chicken Marsala when I received this recipe and wanted to try it!  It turned out so good!  The chicken was so tender and tasty...and the mushrooms were just SO GOOD, next time I am going to add even more mushrooms! My 6 year old son even liked the mushrooms! I loved the sauce to top it with too - I just wish I would've made more, next time I'll use more chicken broth. I did make some changes: First of all I pounded the chicken out, I also added garlic to the salt and pepper (as recommended by another review), I used wondra rather than regular flour (that's usually what I use for chicken marsala), I used Balsalic Vinaigrette rather than Balsalmic Vinegar - but I cut the amount in half as recommended by a lot of reviews and I think it would have tasted even better if I would've just used the whole amount!  Also, I didn't have Bay Leaves or Thyme - so I just used an Italian Seasoning that I had.  SO GOOD!  I will make this again & again!

Wonderful recipe. I didn't flour the chicken as per a lot of reviewers here. I also didn't have any thyme or bay leaves but I used some marjoram in my any-herb-will-do mentality. Also used Portobello breakfast mushrooms (not the button types). As for the vinegar, i myself am neutral to it and i used the full amount. I thought if it was reduced, it wouldn't taste as good. Boyfriend loved it too. Served with rice and stir-fry veges for a complete meal.

text:
I made this exactly according to the recipe and my husband and I both found the chicken to be dry.  I think this has potential, but next time I will cook the chicken for less time before adding in the sauce ingredients.  I also think the cooking times were too long.  Ten minutes was way to long to cook the chicken and seven more minutes reduced my sauce to almost nothing.  I would make this again, but cook it for less time and add some white wine and rosemary to balance the flavors.

I liked this recipe, but I didn't LOVE this recipe. I followed the advice of a lot of other reviewers and doubled the sauce, but I halved the Balsamic vinegar. It was a good dish but not one that I would rave about. My teenage son really liked it, my 9 year old daughter did not, at all. I would like to try it again with fresh cremini mushrooms, I think that might make a HUGE difference. Overall, not great,  just good, will try again. This is a good recipe to use when you have almost no  groceries and are pressed for something basically healthy to put on the table fast.

text:
I've made this twice, both times it was excellent.  The first time I followed the directions, including flouring and sauteeing the chicken.  The second time I did not flour the chicken and added diced tomatoes.  I actually liked it a little better flouring the chicken.  The trick is to flour the chicken and to shake off all excess flour, fry in a hot pan.  The diced tomatoes suggested by another reader was really good also, and will probably be the way I make it from now on. This was really quick and easy, especially if you don't flour the chicken or dice tomatoes.

Just made this for the first time tonight for me and my roommate. We both thought it was great. I took the advice of one of the posters and used portebello mushrooms in the sauce, which were really nice. My only criticism is that I found it was a bit salty once it reduced, and next time I make it I'm going to try using water instead of stock, or maybe half water, half stock. All in all, though, great flavour, simple, quick, and definitely open to playing with. I served this recipe with lightly sauteed asparagus and roasted potatoes with rosemary. Worked beautifully.

text:
Family voted this one a keeper! Tripled the sauce recipe (and mushrooms) and served it with mashed potatoes and a veggie. It was yummy. I did use cut up chicken instead of the boneless, chicken breasts. Worked great, chicken was super-moist. I did not use the flour and pulled the chicken as soon as it temped-out (use a digital meat thermometer for a quick and reliable reading). Used a cornstarch mixture to thicken sauce and then swirled in a bit of butter at the end. Decadent.

Display Name:
TsukiKarp

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a breed of recipe that always makes me sad because it has such POTENTIAL for greatness and yet falls short. The sauce/broth around the chicken turned out VERY delicious, but unlike some concoctions which infuse the meat with the flavor of the sauce, the chicken itself remains bland. It was still relatively "yummy," but not as amazing as I expected from the reviews. What could make it more "amazing"? I suggest doubling the amount of mushrooms (and searching for more WILD mushrooms like chantrelle) and also doubling the garlic, plus lessening the time the chicken is cooked and making sure the breasts are pounded thin & TENDER. But all in all, not a bad recipe by any means... just not heart-stopping amazing.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
This was good.  I used thin sliced chicken breast, added 1/4c white wine to sauce and used jarred minced garlic.  I thought the flavors went very well together.  (No mushrooms, can't stand them.)   It's a nice change from "cream of" type recipes, although my sauce didn't reduce much.  Tasty - will make again. Update:  made again.  still no mushrooms.  no white wine.  used FRESH garlic cloves and coarsely chopped.  cooked chicken, took out, let sauce reduce at least 10 mins with the help of some wondra flour, then dipped chicken in sauce again to warm up.  served with the gourmet mushroom risotto (minus the mushrooms) from this salt, and the balsamic asparagus.  YUMMMMMMM!!!!!!

country:
None
text:
This recipe is SIMPLY AMAZING. I did a few things to alter it to our taste, but overall, the recipe is perfect.

Changes: I reduced the vinegar to 1/8 cup & added in a splash of heavy cream at the end of cooking. The cream turned it into a Balsamic Chicken Stronganoff, which we of course served over buttered egg noodles.

I PROMISE, this recipe will go over GREAT, don't be afraid of the vinegar either, the cream will help take the bitterness out of it.

text:
Wonderful recipe. Used store bought "thin sliced chicken breasts", so it made for a scaloppini - like dish. Because the chicken was so thin, I removed the chicken after browning a few minutes on each side, and added back to the sauce for a minute or two while the sauce was simmering, just to coat the chicken with the yummy sauce. Used only about a tsp of bottled minced garlic. Served with roasted asparagus. Delightful. Can't wait to serve it to guests!

text:
YUM!  I used 6 chicken thighs instead of 4 chicken breasts, but used the full recipe for everything else.  It was a bit vinegar-y, so I added about 1/4 tsp. salt to the sauce towards the end and 1/2 tsp of cornstarch to thicken.  I also diced 4 slices of bacon, precooked & drained them and added it to the sauce at the end as well.  Had a little bit of leftover for lunch the next day -- excellent!  Can't wait to make again!  Thanks!!

text:
This was wonderful!!! I have a new favorite way of preparing boneless, skinless chicken breasts. The only thing I did different was I marinated the chicken in a little balsamic vinegar and olive oil for about an hour before cooking. I also was out of thyme so I substited a pinch of mixed dried herbs that I had. I was afraid that the garlic would burn if I added it when I flipped the chicken so I added it just about a minute before I added the liquid. I most definitely will be making this again, probably very soon.

text:
This recipe is an all-around winner.  I followed the other reviews and used a little more than half the balsamic vinegar called for and it was excellent.  I loved that it had a very "gourmet" flavor as well as appearance and it was very easy to make.  If you want to impress your guest, this is the recipe!
